lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to spoken descriptions and select the correct objects and clothes.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Say: “It’s round. It helps you see.” Students guess: “Glasses!” Play audio and ask them to match descriptions to objects/images.
stretchStrategies: Future Me Posters – Students draw a poster of themselves in 20 years, label features (“I’ll be tall. I’ll have short hair.”), and present to class. Combines listening to descriptions, writing, and oral presentation.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write answers to questions about people’s possessions and what people are wearing using full sentences.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Write a model sentence on the board: “Whose phone is this? It’s Mai’s.” Students answer 3 similar questions in notebooks using SB images.
stretchStrategies: Future Me Posters – Students draw a poster of themselves in 20 years, label features (“I’ll be tall. I’ll have short hair.”), and present to class. Combines listening to descriptions, writing, and oral presentation.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can work together politely and take turns to complete a collaborative activity.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Collaboration) Students work in pairs. One describes a person’s clothes, the other draws it. Compare and describe drawings together.

items: The -ing is often forgotten. Vietnamese does not have different forms of the same verb. I like eat rice.
VYL: many words starting in sibilants prove extremely difficult (shirt, shorts, socks, shoes). Plurals for singular items (trousers, shorts)
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
